title: Information Security Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at Sutter Health in Sept 2021
Interview Descriptions:
Applied for a role on the information security team in mid August 2021. Four days later getting an email that the position had been filled but there is a related and similar role, would I be interested? 

Hmm, role filled in four days is already a red flag but let us see where this goes shall we? 

Conversation with recruiter went well, and the conversation with the hiring manager. In fact, I really liked the hiring manager – they said the right things, had a similar perspective on approach and business needs. 

Next step was a panel with multiple individuals from their security and privacy teams. A little intimidating, but it provided a good basis for understanding the interactions between and the scope of the teams. 

Next was the conversation with the deputy executive in mid-Sepetember, and when things tanked badly. This individual focused on my resume and made the judgement that I was a job hopper, not accepting my explanations or reasoning, and determined I would leave them as well. He then went on about he had been at his last job for ten years and could not understand why some else was not able to do the same, they just had two people leave, and they needed folks to stay there for the long haul. 

Honestly, I was dumbfounded as to the logical fallacies and his white male entitlement being used to dismiss my background and experience with his inability and/or unwillingness to grasp how others not as fortunate or advantaged, that are disabled veterans, had to experience a bad employer/toxic work environment, neurodiversity, or just plain unlucky may contribute to a work history. If this indicated how short-sighted, callous, and unprofessional this judgmental executive would be during an interview, how would this carry over when working on their team? No wonder they have people leaving! 

Then silence for weeks.

In the third week of November 2021, I received the canned rejection email from their ATS. The role was reposted to their ATS and the job posting sites the next morning. So they would rather keep searching for the unicorn candidate rather than give someone a chance. 

I want to work with true leaders, not judgmental managers who are stuck in their own logical fallacies for years. If this is how they treat candidates, this has me questioning how do they treat you as a patient? I will never apply for a job at Sutter ever again, will never get my medical care from Sutter; and will recommend to everyone who asks to avoid Sutter as a medical provider or an employer.
Interview Questions: Are you comfortable with commuting onsite three days a week to the work location?

title: Registered Nurse Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Sutter Health (San Francisco, CA)
Interview Descriptions:
So the interview itself was amazing. The people interviewing asked relevant questions pertaining to the job. They were very interactive. 

The bad review is for the recruiter. Like any job, I submitted my resume that had every experience that pertained to nursing. A few days after my interview, I get a call that I am offered a position. I of course accept. A week later I receive an email that I rejected the offer? Hmm that’s weird. So I call the recruiter and asked what happened. She tells me there is a sutter rule that internal transfers cannot occur within 6 months of being hired at another sutter facility. I was working at another sutter facility and officially quit already since I received an offer. I told the recruiter that it was in my resume. I was not aware of this rule, and was confused why they didn’t automatically reject my application due to this rule. 

So be careful if you are doing a transfer from another sutter facility. Make sure you work six months first. Also be aware that the recruiter doesn’t clearly look at your resume. Obviously the recruiter didn’t look at mine. Luckily my wife makes enough money for me to be out of a job temporarily since I quit my job because I received that offer.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Billing Analyst Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Sutter Health

title: Regulatory Privacy & Information Security Analyst, Awareness & Training Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2+ months. I interviewed at Sutter Health (Roseville, CA) in Aug 2019
Interview Descriptions:
It was a long process but the offer was well worth it. I had a phone screen interview, a phone interview, a panel interview, and a one-on-one with the Senior Deputy Chief Information Security Officer.

All of the interviews were straightforward, and everyone had a relaxed attitude. The only stress involved was the stress I brought in with me. Very nice people and great experience all around.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself.

title: Human Resources Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Sutter Health (Mountain View, CA) in Aug 2019
Interview Descriptions:
I was had a total of 4 interviews, 1) phone interview with the recruiter 2) phone interview with the hiring manager 3) onsite interview with the hiring manager and finally 4) a panel interview.  I was not selected for the position, which is fine, PAMF needs to hire the right person for their positions.

What I take exception to is how I learned that I was not selected.  I received a impersonal form email that I was not selected.  When an candidate goes through 4 in depth interviews and they are not selected it is disrespectful and unprofessional to send an impersonal email.  In all my years of being in HR if a candidate was in the final interviews they always received either a personal phone call from the recruiter or a personal email.  I certainly  wouldn't send a form email to a candidate.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work in healthcare?

title: Claims Adjuster Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Sutter Health (Sacramento, CA) in Apr 2019
Interview Descriptions:
I applied online
My first call was with a HR rep who asked me about the job and my background. She mostly wanted to know why  I was interested. I tried then to ask about salary but she wouldn't discuss that with me. It was a 15 minute phone call. 

I was then scheduled for an in-person panel interview with 4 people (but it ended up being 3 after one guy called out sick); this took about 45 minutes but they round-robined a bunch of questions about how I would handle scenarios like a difficult customer or working with multiple departments to get things done. 

After my interview, I was given 20 minutes to write down answers to a scenario of a worker's compensation injury and how I would investigate it and reserves for that body part. 

About a week after my in-person interview, I got a call from the person that would have been my direct supervisor (since he was absent from the in-person meeting) because he wanted to feel me out and get to know me more. He wants to ask me about my hobbies, what I knew about Sutter Health as an organization, and confirm that I knew that this wasn't going to be an upgrade from my current job. I, again, tried to ask about salary since it wasn't posted online. 

I got a call a week after that with a job offer but once salary was discussed (which apparently they offered me middle of the payscale), I wasn't able to take it because it was too low.
Interview Questions: Give an example of a time that you dealt with an irate injured worker, what did you do?

title: HR Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Sutter Health (San Francisco, CA) in Nov 2018
Interview Descriptions:
Well, let this be a lesson on first impressions. Because, wow, did I have a first impression. 

Phone interview: Scattered and unorganized. Many red flags but decided to take the in person interview, because why not. 

In person interview: Rude and rushed. They didn't schedule a conference room so the interview was in the lobby, which is loud and is obviously not intended for a 1:1 conversation. The Recruiter answers her phone in the middle of interview and says that she has an appointment and will need to leave early. Thanks for the warning, but, why did you schedule it during this time in the first place if you knew you had to leave? After 30 min of talking, I'm out of the blue ushered to a conference room with two other people. During the interview, it's very apparent that no one has looked at my resume before I arrive. One person I've already had a phone interview with, the other just spoke to me in the lobby, and the third had never met me before. The layout of the interview was awkward because I'm trying to simultaneously catch one person up on who I am while answering the questions. 

Something that I've taken from my years of recruiting is knowing how to judge an organization based on my candidate experience. For instance, I would never answer my phone in the middle of an interview nor would I have an interview in the middle of a hospital lobby. This signaled to me that 1. My time is not being valued. 2. Things are so disorganized that a conference room couldn't be scheduled ahead of time. 

So yes, in the end, I didn't move forward in the process. Was I sad? Not in the least. You're welcome to chalk this review up to be another "bitter review from someone who didn't get the offer." 

I'm writing this review in some hope that the HR team at Sutter reads this and figures out how to make some major adjustments in their interview process, or lack thereof.
Interview Questions: Let's say there is someone who doesn't like or hates you - what would they say about you?

title: ICU RN Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Sutter Health (Santa Rosa, CA) in Jul 2018
Interview Descriptions:
It was disappointing to say the least. Interesting enough, in December the ICU wanted me to take a travel assignment based off of my resume alone; not even an interview needed. Unfortunately they pulled the contract altogether before I could accept it. Then in February I applied for 3 of their night FT positions and received a call from their recruiter, who asked me random personality based questions and then setup an interview for me in the ICU. 

At the last minute I received a text message from the "ICU interviewer" stating she needs to reschedule, so I did and met at her office in the ICU. The interview was not very formal and it really just went over my resume and previous work that I had not listed (i.e. non RN, but pt care roles), but no real in depth scenario or knowledge based questions. She did mention that she had some new nurses on nights. She said she would speak to my references and get back to me and told me to email her if I had any questions. I did email with some questions while thanking her for the interview. However her reply did not bother addressing my inquiries and just said I don’t have enough experience although my resume states otherwise and they wanted my travel contract in December based on my resume alone. 

So over the last 4 months there have been openings and recently 5 ICU night positions. It appears the Staff turnaround is high there and most likely need staff more than the staff needs them. I applied and a month later I get a call from the same "ICU interviewer," who had no idea she had talked to me before. We setup an interview and I met with her in her office again. 

She recognized me, she inquired, and I told her she didn’t hire me. She asked why and when I began to state the above someone barged in the office asking questions about an ER admit, getting a patient out, etc., etc. The person left and the "interviewer" apologized while holding her phone and text messaging, which went on for the majority of the interview. Again, no knowledge or scenario based questions.

The first request was to tell her about myself. As I went on from the beginning of my hospital career 8yrs ago and discussed my different roles and experience at each job, she interjected and wanted to know about my time in ICU. Most of my time as a nurse had been step-down ICU until now where it’s been mostly ICU.

I am currently on a travel contract at a nearby facility in the ICU and she concluded that it’s not an adequate ICU although I stated that I take vented patients on ICU drips. She asked about my preceptors back home and said she would need to speak with them because  there has been too much of a gap between when I worked back home until now (6mo) and I basically don’t have my skills current. That was not an issue in February, but apparently it is now. She also mentioned that she has 5 brand new graduate nurses and needs someone with experience. So basically, they can’t keep staff, so they hire nurses with zero experience, but won’t hire nurses with 8yrs bedside care, 4yrs RN (2yrs as step-down ICU, 2+yrs ICU) experience. 

I stated that back in FL, the work experience is exponential without the unions or patient ratios to protect nurses. Medical staff are put to the test every single day back home. While text messaging,  she just said she would need my references and gave me her card, so that I could email them to her. 

I emailed my references to her the next day, my references were waiting for a phone call, but the next morning I received an email again saying I don’t have enough experience. My references were never contacted. I replied back to the email questions that decision and the rationale for everything stated above, not expecting a job, but wanting a logical reason for such inconsistent reasons and telling me one thing, while not giving me a professional interview, and doing something else entirely.

Not a good representation of what I thought would be a great place to work. Obviously they need to fill ICU positions regularly. It seems they need staff more than the staff needs them as reflected by the multiple job listings. I considered staying in CA and making Santa Rosa my home, coming back to my home state of CA. It would take a lot now to make me reconsider that. It’s their loss. 

The only reason the interview was difficult is because of the lack of professionalism on her mobile phone and not really giving undivided attention, and not following through with what she said she would do. If I got the job, the interview would have been simple because no challenging questions were asked. They would rather hire people with zero experience, who will most likely make many mistakes rather than hire someone with 2yrs experience, which is not enough experience. However that makes sense, I will never know. It’s probably not a facility I would feel comfortable trusting or working with.
Interview Questions: I was not asked any real questions to determine my knowledge, critical thinking, skill set, or anything that all other managers ask at other hospitals. It was not very professional. Everything asked was printed on my resume, which just pertained to the amount of time worked at my last jobs.
